articles.headline: Europe Seen Avoiding Keynes’s Cure for Recession
articles.snippet: In the land of his birth, John Maynard Keynes’s view that deficit spending is crucial to avoiding a long recession has lately been willfully ignored.
articles.abstract: In the land of his birth, John Maynard Keynes’s view that deficit spending is crucial to avoiding a long recession has lately been willfully ignored.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  The British economist John Maynard Keynes may live on in popular legend as the world’s most influential economist. But in much of Europe, and most acutely here in the land of his birth, his view that deficit spending by governments is crucial to avoiding a long recession has lately been willfully ignored.

articles.headline: Battling the Earbud Blues
articles.snippet: Do you suffer from Earbud Cartilage Deficiency Syndrome? Don’t worry. A range of earphone accessories can help you keep those earbuds in place.
articles.abstract: Do you suffer from Earbud Cartilage Deficiency Syndrome? Don’t worry. A range of earphone accessories can help you keep those earbuds in place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do you have trouble making iPod earbuds stay in your ears? Does the least bit of exercise make them fall out?

articles.headline: Graco Recalls Strollers on Strangulation Concerns
articles.snippet: The Graco products, sold before 2008, were linked to the strangulation of four infants.
articles.abstract: The Graco products, sold before 2008, were linked to the strangulation of four infants.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the largest recall of strollers ever, Graco Children’s Products on Wednesday urged the owners of about two million older-model strollers to stop using them because of concerns about possible strangulation.

articles.headline: Rare Vote Set on a Union in Fast Food
articles.snippet: Employees at the sandwich chain Jimmy John’s in Minneapolis will vote in one of the few efforts to organize fast-food workers.
articles.abstract: Employees at the sandwich chain Jimmy John’s in Minneapolis will vote in one of the few efforts to organize fast-food workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS  The Jimmy John’s restaurants here are known for serving attitude with their sandwiches. Many of their young workers wear nose rings, beards and dreadlocks, and the shops sport mottoes like “The Customer Is Usually Right” and “Subs So Fast You’ll Freak.”

articles.headline: Battle Lines Forming in Clash Over Foreclosures
articles.snippet: Courts are expected to be flooded with cases against lenders trying to foreclose without proper records.
articles.abstract: Courts are expected to be flooded with cases against lenders trying to foreclose without proper records.
articles.lead_paragraph: About a month after Washington Mutual Bank made a multimillion-dollar mortgage loan on a mountain home near Santa Barbara, Calif., a crucial piece of paperwork disappeared.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: 3 Schools of Thought on Wealth Management
articles.snippet: Investment advisers are trying to focus on the future rather than on the losses of the past. Broadly, they have taken three approaches: the caring, the technical and the retirement-focused.
articles.abstract: Investment advisers are trying to focus on the future rather than on the losses of the past. Broadly, they have taken three approaches: the caring, the technical and the retirement-focused.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS portfolios tick up after the vast losses of two years ago, many investors remain wary. The latest whiz-bang product is more likely to inspire skepticism than desire. Promises of steady returns do not inspire confidence, either.

articles.headline: Foreclosures Profit Some Equity Firms
articles.snippet: Several private equity firms or entities they control have stakes in the business operations of some of the busiest foreclosure law firms.
articles.abstract: Several private equity firms or entities they control have stakes in the business operations of some of the busiest foreclosure law firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a surge in lawsuits against law firms specializing in foreclosures, a case in Mississippi is casting light on another aspect of the mortgage mess  the connection between Wall Street private equity firms and those law firms, often known as foreclosure mills.

articles.headline: Climate Change Doubt Is Tea Party Article of Faith
articles.snippet: The movement’s supporters are wary of the Obama administration’s plans to regulate carbon dioxide.
articles.abstract: The movement’s supporters are wary of the Obama administration’s plans to regulate carbon dioxide.
articles.lead_paragraph: JASPER, Ind. — At a candidate forum here last week, Representative Baron P. Hill, a threatened Democratic incumbent in a largely conservative southern Indiana district, was endeavoring to explain his unpopular vote for the House cap-and-trade energy bill.

articles.headline: As Dollar’s Value Falls, Currency Conflicts Rise
articles.snippet: It seems like every nation for itself as economic rivals try to turn exchange rates to their advantage.
articles.abstract: It seems like every nation for itself as economic rivals try to turn exchange rates to their advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is this a currency war or what?

articles.headline: Coalition Forces Routing Taliban in Key Afghan Region
articles.snippet: With the help of a highly accurate mobile rocket, a buildup of American and Afghan forces seems to have forced many insurgents to flee strongholds in Kandahar Province.
articles.abstract: With the help of a highly accurate mobile rocket, a buildup of American and Afghan forces seems to have forced many insurgents to flee strongholds in Kandahar Province.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  American and Afghan forces have been routing the Taliban in much of Kandahar Province in recent weeks, forcing many hardened fighters, faced with the buildup of American forces, to flee strongholds they have held for years, NATO commanders, local Afghan officials and residents of the region said.

articles.headline: Efforts to Prosecute Blackwater Are Collapsing
articles.snippet: The cases involving killings in Iraq and Afghanistan raise questions about the use of private contractors.
articles.abstract: The cases involving killings in Iraq and Afghanistan raise questions about the use of private contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nearly four years after the federal government began a string of investigations and criminal prosecutions against Blackwater Worldwide personnel accused of murder and other violent crimes in Iraq and Afghanistan, the cases are beginning to fall apart, burdened by a legal obstacle of the government’s own making.

articles.headline: Water Scarcity a Bond Risk, Study Warns
articles.snippet: Researchers say that many municipal bonds may be riskier than investors realize because ratings do not adequately reflect the risks of water shortages.
articles.abstract: Researchers say that many municipal bonds may be riskier than investors realize because ratings do not adequately reflect the risks of water shortages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The municipal bonds that help finance a major portion of the nation’s water supply may be riskier than investors realize because their credit ratings do not adequately reflect the growing risks of water shortages and legal battles over water supplies, according to a new study.
articles.byline: By Felicity Barringer and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: Fannie and Freddie May Need Infusion
articles.snippet: Taxpayers could be on the hook for tens of billions in further support, depending on how the housing market fares, regulators say.
articles.abstract: Taxpayers could be on the hook for tens of billions in further support, depending on how the housing market fares, regulators say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The federal bailout of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac may be winding down with relatively little additional cost to taxpayers so long as the economy continues to recover. But if the economy tips back into recession, the bailout could nearly double in size, according to new government projections announced on Thursday.
